Award.AwardTitle: RI: Doctoral Student Workshop at the Fourth Annual Conference on Advances in Cognitive Systems

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project supports the Doctoral Student Workshop at the Fourth Annual Conference in Cognitive Systems to be held at Northwestern University in June 2016. Cognitive Systems is an international and interdisciplinary conference series covering all aspects of research on cognitive computing. It is distinguished by a focus on high-level cognition and decision-making, reliance on rich, structured representations, a systems-level perspective, and the incorporation of insights about human thinking. The goal of the doctoral student symposium is to encourage, expand, and guide the participation of young researchers starting research in cognitive computing

Cognitive computing has recently had major successes, represented by well- known systems like IBM's Watson, Microsoft's Cortana, Google's Now, and Apple's Siri, among many others. The Advances in Cognitive Systems conference fosters research carried out in the original spirit of AI, which aimed to design and implement computer programs that exhibited the breadth, generality, and flexibility often observed in human intelligence. We expect the Fourth Annual Conference on Cognitive Systems to significantly increase our understanding of cognitive computing, and add momentum to the development of new theories, techniques and tools for cognitive computing. The conference sessions and workshops will help develop human research capital by enabling interactions between senior and junior researchers and catalyzing new collaborations. The doctoral student workshop will increase the exposure and visibility of young graduate student researchers in these areas, and train them by providing early input and feedback in the field in an interactive and constructive environment.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Students of Cognitive Systems Workshop of the Advances in Cognitive Systems Conference was held last summer, June 23rd 2016, at Northwestern University. SOCS-16 was aimed at PhD students who had recently proposed or were soon to propose a thesis topic and was organized with the following goals:

  • To introduce students to cognitive systems research early in their academic career
  • To give students the opportunity to present their research to their peers and other researchers
  • To pair students with mentors who are further along in their careers
  • To discuss key challenges, evaluation methodologies, best practices, and ongoing research efforts in Cognitive Systems research
  • To foster a culture of collaboration across several research labs that are pursuing research in cognitive systems and other related fields

This is the second such workshop to have been organized. SOCS-16 saw seven participating students from five universities including one international student. All students also attended the full ACS conference. Each student was paired with one of three mentors who were senior researchers in the field: Larry Birnbaum (faculty NU/co-founder Narrative Science), Tom Hinrichs (research faculty NU), and Laura Hiatt (researcher NRL). Mentors provided individual feedback on thesis topics and presentations before and during the conference as well as career advice.

The workshop also included a keynote speech by Larry Birnbaum on automatic narrative construction as well as a career panel consisting of the three mentors and Dylan Schmorrow from SOAR Technology.
